entry.title: All you need to know about Radiant Capital V2
entry.content:
What is Radiant Capital?

RadiantCapital is a cross-chain DeFi lending protocol. The team positions itself as an omnichain lending protocol, aiming to realize leveraged lending and composability between different chains.

Problems RadiantCapital wants to solve

  1. Fragmented Liquidity: The fragmentation of liquidity across different blockchain chains has been a significant challenge in the DeFi space. The Radiant DAO’s mission is to unify the billions in fragmented liquidity across Web3 money markets under one safe, user-friendly, capital-efficient omnichain protocol.
  2. Reliance on Third-Party Bridges: By migrating to LayerZero OFT format, Radiant Capital aims to enable seamless cross-chain transactions, enhancing the security and efficiency of cross-chain transactions.
  3. Oracle Manipulation: Radiant Capital focuses on core offerings resilient to Oracle manipulation, ensuring the integrity and reliability of its financial products and services[2].

Value Proposition

  1. Unified Liquidity: By consolidating fragmented liquidity across different chains, Radiant Capital offers users the ability to access major assets on any major chain, enhancing the efficiency of the DeFi ecosystem[1].
  2. Innovative Features: Radiant Capital’s v2 upgrade and integration with Layer Zero introduce revolutionary changes to core protocol mechanics, emissions, utility, and deeper cross-chain functionality, providing users with competitive interest opportunities and safety[1, 2].
  3. Long-Term Engagement: Through incentives that scale with locking duration, Radiant Capital fosters long-term engagement, benefiting token lockers, lenders, and DAO expenses[3].
  4. Community Engagement: With the native utility token RDNT, Radiant Capital seeks to foster community engagement and participation in the platform’s growth and governance. Radiant Capital provides tutorials and a community-driven approach, making it accessible to both new and experienced users in the DeFi space[3].

How Radiant Capital Works

Radiant’s operational framework is quite straightforward: To utilize Radiant’s cross-chain lending services, users must first deposit specified assets on supported chains (currently, only Arbitrum and BNB Chain are supported, and ETH Mainnet is coming), thus becoming dynamic liquidity providers (dLP). Only then can they lend the necessary assets on the target chain. The fees accrued by the Radiant V2 protocol are distributed in the following manner: 60% is apportioned to dynamic liquidity providers (dLP), 25% to the depositors (Lenders), and the remaining 15% is designated for DAO-controlled Operating Expenses Wallet, of which the use will be governed by a future on-chain proposal.

By using Radiant, users can place assets like ETH, WBTC, or other related collateral on Arbitrum, and then borrow BNB on BSC, effectively leveraging their holdings. During this borrowing procedure, users are exempted from any cross-chain operations, meaning there’s no need to transfer assets from one chain to another, such as from Arbitrum to BSC, in the example provided. This feature simplifies the user experience, enabling cross-chain or Layer 2 lending activities without having to physically move assets between different chains. Radiant also offers a unique one-click loop function that allows users to enhance the value of their collateral by utilizing automated cycles of deposits and loans.

Radiant v2

In Radiant V1, the cross-chain operations were predominantly facilitated through Stargate’s cross-chain routing mechanism. One of Radiant v2’s first priorities will be to move ERC-20 RDNT token to the LayerZero OFT (Omnichain Fungible Token) format. This migration will make cross-chain fee sharing much more seamless, enable quicker launches on additional chains, and permit native ownership of bridging contracts rather than relying on third-party bridges.

In its V2 version, Radiant has introduced Dynamic Liquidity Provisioning (dLP) to tackle the inflation problem associated with the RDNT token. With this change, users only making deposits will only be eligible for the basic interest rate, excluding them from RDNT token rewards. To qualify for these rewards, they must lock in dLP tokens equivalent to at least 5% of their total deposit value. For example, If User 1 deposits 1M USDC into the Radiant market but has zero of dLP tokens locked, they would be eligible to receive a base deposit yield but would NOT be eligible for RDNT emissions. On the other hand, if User 2 puts 1M USDC into Radiant and has $50,000 worth of RDNT/BNB dLP locked, this user would be eligible for RDNT emissions (assuming the minimum 5% threshold continues to be met).

Currently, Radiant offers two locked LP (Liquidity Provider) pools:

  • Arbitrum: Balancer with an 80/20 composition (80% RDNT & 20% ETH)
  • BNB Chain: Pancakeswap with a 50/50 composition (50% RDNT & 50% BNB)

dLP tokens currently support lock-in periods ranging from 1 to 12 months, with the corresponding token incentives increasing with the length of the lock-in period. Auto-relock will also be added as an option. The earned token rewards will be linearly released over a 3-month span. During this time, if users do not wish to wait, they can apply for early exit with a penalty, allowing them to obtain between 10% and 75% of the token rewards, as shown below.

To improve the ease of use, Radiant added zaps for virtually every component introduced in v2: adding liquidity, looping, and adding dLP — there is even a zap to loop + deposit 5% dLP all at once.

Radiant has innovatively introduced Dynamic Liquidity Provisioning (dLP) to its platform, transforming the way depositors can earn RDNT token rewards. This new feature necessitates depositors to contribute a specified proportion of liquidity, consequently boosting RDNT’s demand and locked-up volume, and enhancing its overall liquidity. This strategy not only promotes the appeal of RDNT but also aligns with the interests of medium to long-term liquidity contributors, fostering a mutually beneficial relationship between them and the platform.

In a move towards long-term sustainability, Radiant, in its V2 version, has elongated the token release period from 2 to 5 years (ending in July 2027). Simultaneously, adjustments to the V1 reward and penalty mechanism were made, including the extension of the attribution time frame from 28 to 90 days and modifying the early withdrawal reward structure to a linear 10%-75%.

Additionally, for unclaimed expired rewards, users will be removed from the incentive pool but have the option to initiate re-locking through the interface. The protocol’s fees have also been restructured, with Dynamic Liquidity Providers (dLP) emerging as the leading beneficiaries.

These comprehensive changes in the V2 version represent a more thoughtful and balanced approach, aligning more closely with both short-term and long-term strategic objectives, as compared to the initial V1 design.

OFT (Omnichain Fungible Tokens)

OFT, or Omnichain Fungible Token, represents an innovative approach to seamless interconnectivity between different chains supported by LayerZero. Functioning as a common token standard across these chains, OFT can effortlessly be moved from one chain to another, without the need for additional costs typically associated with cross-chain transfers. During a transfer, OFT is destroyed on the originating chain and recreated on the destination chain, maintaining its integrity and value.

As of the current Radiant V2 version, OFT’s utility is specifically tailored to Radiant’s native token RDNT. This specialized implementation permits RDNT to be amalgamated and divided across LayerZero’s supported chains, thus realigning the liquidity of the asset. Consequently, RDNT enjoys an adaptable supply on each chain, allowing for the development of intricate financial strategies and frequent arbitrage opportunities, which further diversify the token’s applications.

Roadmap

Radiant’s future development roadmap includes the complete integration of LayerZero within its upcoming V3 and V4 versions. This integration aims to facilitate an uninterrupted cross-chain experience, broadening support for additional EVM chains in cross-chain borrowing and lending. By merging with LayerZero, Radiant addresses a long-standing issue of fragmentation in the crypto space, empowering users with the ability to utilize a consistent token standard across numerous chains. This harmonization not only enriches the user experience but also sets the stage for frictionless collateralization and lending of native tokens across LayerZero-supported networks within Radiant’s ecosystem.

Radiant Performance

The provided information can be observed in the image sourced from DefiLlama above. With minimal value locked in Radiant V1 following its migration, it is reasonable to consider Radiant V2’s performance as reflective of these numbers. Notably, the Total Value Locked (TVL) has exhibited substantial growth since the start of 2023, surging multiple times to reach 280 million USD TVL, and currently stabilizing at 248 million USD. However, the market capitalization has displayed a roller coaster pattern, peaking at 136 million USD, a nearly tenfold increase from the beginning of 2023, and currently resting at 86 million USD. The Market Cap to Total Value Locked Ratio (TVL Ratio) offers valuable insights into the correlation between a DeFi project’s valuation and its demand. In the case of Radiant, a relatively lower market cap contrasts with a higher TVL, resulting in a TVL ratio of approximately 0.35. This ratio potentially signifies an undervaluation of the token.

Based on insights from the Dune Analytics data portal, following its initial gradual adoption, Radiant protocol experienced a swift surge in user engagement during the Arbitrum frenzy. However, with the introduction of Radiant’s V2 version, the pace of user expansion notably decelerated, leading to a more stabilized count of both new and existing wallets.

Radiant has made significant strides in its market presence thus far. However, the data analysis provided above also underscores an interesting trend within Radiant. Specifically, under the circumstances of stable or rising RDNT prices combined with robust liquidity mining incentives, both deposits and borrowings within Radiant are poised for potential further growth. However, it’s worth noting that Radiant’s competitive edge could wane should the landscape of mining rewards become more challenging. Moreover, in terms of user engagement, Radiant appears to have encountered a plateau following the introduction of its V2 version.

Presently, Radiant’s strategic focus centers on broadening its reach across additional blockchain networks and diversifying its support for various collateral assets. By expanding its service scope and garnering enhanced user participation, Radiant aims to fuel its next phase of expansion. Looking ahead, the protocol’s ultimate success hinges on its ability to tangibly drive widespread adoption of cross-chain lending in practical applications. On July 23, 2023, RDNT capital tweeted: After the successful demonstration of Arbitrum to BNB CHAIN, RFP-19 indicates that the next step for Radiant DAO is Ethereum. With Ethereum holding 26 billion in Total Value Locked (TVL) and 70 billion in underutilized stablecoins, it presents a significant growth opportunity, which can lead to substantial growth in both TVL & dLP for Radiant protocol.

Tokenomics

RDNT has a total supply of 1,000,000,000 tokens. The exact monthly emission rate is calculated as $20,000,000/1.0568^n$, where n is the number of months since the v2 launch.

  • 49% emitted as incentives for suppliers and borrowers, released over five years
  • 19% to the team, released over five years, with a three-month cliff (10% of the team allocation is locked at the genesis of the protocol and unlocks at the 3-month cliff)
  • 17% allocated to the Radiant DAO Reserve that comprises (1) 50% of ‘Incentives - Supply and Borrowers’ emissions from Oct 2022 - March 2023, and (2) 85% of ‘Incentives - Pool 2’ from Aug 3, 2022, through Feb 2023, ratified in RFP-2 governance proposal
  • 7% allocated to core contributors and advisors, released over one and a half years
  • 6% reserved for the Treasury & LP, ratified in RFP-9 governance proposal
  • 2% emitted for Pool 2 liquidity providers between August 3, 2022, through March 17, 2023, which has been deprecated and ratified in RFP-8 governance proposal

Only users with locked Dynamic Liquidity (Liquidity Tokens) activate eligibility to receive RDNT emissions within the money market. RDNT Liquidity mining emissions can be instantly claimed for the total amount on the condition that they are zapped into locked dLP tokens by pairing the claimed $RDNT with wstETH/BNB. Alternatively, emissions may be vested for three months. Vesting RDNT may be claimed early for an exit penalty to receive 10-75% of rewards, decaying linearly during the three-month vesting period. This penalty fee is then distributed 90% to the Radiant DAO reserve, and the remaining 10% is sent to the Radiant Starfleet Treasury.

Radiant Capital has a total token supply of 1 billion. In the V2 version, the token release period has been extended to 5 years (until July 2027), providing a longer duration for token incentives. $RDNT tokens serve similar purposes to governance tokens in other DeFi protocols, being utilized for community governance and liquidity incentives.

Team

Radiant mentioned in an April blog post that Radiant Capital has a 14-member team with prior experience at Morgan Stanley, Apple, and Google. While anonymous teams can present risks, they may cause trust issues, lack accountability, transparency, and face marketing challenges. Investors and users prefer transparent teams for greater credibility and trust.

Funding

Radiant Capital, a full-chain lending protocol on Arbitrum, received 3.34 million $ARB tokens during the recent Arbitrum DAOs Airdrop. On July 20, Binance Ventures invested 10 million USD in Radiant Capital. The new funds will be used for technology and product development, which includes expanding collateral and deployment on the Ethereum mainnet.

Competition: AAVE V3

Compared with Aave, Radiant Capital emphasizes enabling users to access major assets on any main chain and enhances the DeFi ecosystem’s efficiency by integrating fragmented liquidity across different chains while also offering lending services. As an example, users can deposit assets like ETH and USDT on Arbitrum and borrow assets such as BNB on BSC, and ETH on Ethereum. The borrowing process allows users to access different chains or L2 without the need for cross-chain asset transfers. This seamless experience enables users to easily engage in borrowing activities across various platforms.

According to Defillama’s data, as of August 7th, approximately 57% of the total value locked (TVL) is on Ethereum L1, while the remaining TVL is distributed across various other chains. Borrowing activities on these different chains are conducted independently, resulting in fragmented liquidity. RDNT aims to address the issue of liquidity fragmentation between different chains/L2 solutions, thus creating a seamless cross-chain borrowing market.

In the introduction of Aave V3, a new feature called “Portal” is highlighted. This feature enables seamless asset movement between different networks within the Aave V3 ecosystem. The process is straightforward: users provide liquidity on one network, and they can transfer it to another network by burning A Token on Chain A (e.g., Ethereum) and minting them on Chain B (e.g., BSC).

To implement the Portal feature, third-party cross-chain bridge protocols are involved. These bridges need to be whitelisted through Aave governance voting. It means that “burn-mint” operations on different chains are handled by these “whitelisted bridges” rather than the Aave protocol itself, introducing an element of third-party security assumption. The Aave V3 proposal has successfully passed votes to include Hashflow/Wormhole and Stargate as “whitelisted bridges” for V3 Portals.

Aave, being the largest lending protocol in the cryptocurrency market, could establish itself as the most liquid lending platform by introducing multi-chain lending services. The implementation of the Portal feature is expected to enhance liquidity and capital utilization within the Aave ecosystem, potentially making it a formidable competitor to Radiant. However, Radiant holds the advantage of being a first mover in this space. Furthermore, as Layer 0 continues to develop in the oracle and relay domain, Radiant may gain a competitive edge in terms of asset cross-chain security assumptions.

The end

In conclusion, RDNT (Radiant Token) stands as a promising project in the ever-evolving world of decentralized finance. With its innovative V2 version and focus on dynamic liquidity provisioning, RDNT aims to bridge the gap between different chains, providing users with seamless access to major assets across various networks. By addressing liquidity fragmentation and fostering a holistic lending market, RDNT seeks to become a driving force in the DeFi ecosystem.

Cryptocurrency trading and investment involve inherent risks, including market volatility, regulatory changes, and potential loss of funds. Before making any financial decisions, it is essential to conduct thorough research, seek professional advice, and only invest what you can afford to lose. Layer 2 war is on fire: Developments in Layer 2 networks

With the impending Cancun upgrade, Layer2 networks have emerged as the most prominent theme in the latter half of 2023. From July onwards, Layer2 has consistently held a Total Value Locked (TVL) exceeding 10 billion US dollars. In recent days, numerous public chains have declared a transition to Layer2, with some even obtaining significant financial backing.

On July 12th, Manta Network, a public chain operating on a ZK-based Layer1, revealed its new Layer2 network, Manta Pacific, purpose-built for zero-knowledge proof (ZK) applications, utilizing OP Stack. Just a week later, on July 19th, p0x labs, the developer behind Manta Network, successfully raised 25 million USD in a Series A funding round, achieving a valuation of $500 million, with Polychain Capital and Qiming Venture Partners serving as co-leaders. In the midst of these developments, on July 17th, cLabs put forth a proposal to transition Celo from a standalone EVM-compatible Layer1 blockchain to an Ethereum Layer2 structure, also employing OP Stack technology.

Alongside the well-known shift from Layer 1 to Layer 2 networks, the existing Layer 2 networks have seen a flurry of activity and announcements. This includes major players in the Rollup series networks such as Arbitrum, zkSync, and StarkNet, all of which have unveiled open-source toolkit Stacks for the construction of Layer3 networks. In addition, the Optimistic Rollup fork project MetisDAO Foundation has introduced its newly-incubated Hybrid Rollup series project ZKM, while Loopring Protocol has announced plans to build its own Layer3 layer using the zkEVM Layer2 network Taiko.

This series of developments underscore the fact that the Layer2 market has reached an intense and competitive phase. As shown by data from the crypto analytics platform Rootdata, there are now 77 recognized Layer2-related network infrastructures encompassing various elements like modular blockchains, zkRollup, Optimistic Rollup, and application chains. At present, the Layer2 market is primarily being led by two popular scaling solutions: Optimistic Rollup and zkRollup.

So, what are the representative networks of the Optimistic Rollup series and zkRollup series? Let’s dive into the development of them and find the potential opportunities.

Arbitrum

As of the 1st of August, the Arbitrum chain boasts a Total Value Locked (TVL) of approximately 5.96 billion USD, a figure that places it at the forefront of Layer2 projects globally. The chain’s native token, ARB, which was officially launched for trading in March 2023, is presently valued at 1.16 USD. With a circulating supply of 1.28 billion ARB and a total issuance of 10 billion, the market capitalization stands at an impressive 1.49 billion USD, earning a rank of 37th within the crypto asset market. Moreover, the Arbitrum chain leads the Layer2 landscape in various other aspects, including the quantity of deployed ecological applications and overall levels of vitality and activity.

As indicated by the Arbitrum Portal, the official gateway to the Arbitrum ecosystem, there are currently 567 included projects that span various sectors. These encompass applications ranging from wallets and cross-chain bridges to decentralized exchanges (DEX), lending mechanisms, games, and NFT platforms. Among these are widely recognized migrated applications such as Uniswap, Aave, Curve, and 1inch. Alongside these, the Arbitrum ecosystem is also home to innovative native solutions including GMX, a decentralized perpetual contracts system; Radiant Capital, a full-chain lending platform with the support from Layer Zero; Camelot, a native decentralized exchange; and Treasure DAO, a metaverse gaming ecosystem.

Arbitrum, launched in August 2021, stands as a Layer2 scaling solution founded on Optimistic Rollup. Within the Arbitrum ecosystem, there are three distinct networks, each serving specific purposes: Arbitrum One, Arbitrum Nova, and Arbitrum Orbit.

  • Arbitrum One: Acting as the nucleus of the Arbitrum ecosystem, Arbitrum One is the core Rollup chain with all its transactional data housed on Ethereum’s mainnet. Often referred to as L2, this network facilitates on-chain ecosystem applications. Notably, Arbitrum One underwent an upgrade called Arbitrum Nitro, but retained its original name post-upgrade.
  • Arbitrum Nova: Specifically tailored for gaming, social applications, and high-throughput DApp scenarios, Arbitrum Nova leverages AnyTrust technology. Unlike Arbitrum One, which ensures security through Ethereum, Arbitrum Nova offers lower security but compensates with 90% reduced gas fees. It is particularly apt for applications demanding high-frequency trading and minimal transaction fees, such as gaming and social platforms. Real-world applications include the Reddit community point system (like MOON), and the NFT markets launched by Opensea and TreasureDAO on Arbitrum Nova.
  • Arbitrum Orbit: Serving as a development platform, Arbitrum Orbit is an open-source toolkit for constructing L3 networks. Developers can craft their Rollup and AnyTrust chains (L3) using the Orbit toolkit, electing either Arbitrum One or Arbitrum Nova as the settlement layer to achieve scalability. This selection process embodies a strategic balance between decentralization and performance. Several applications have already joined forces with Arbitrum Orbit to establish their own L3 networks. The Ethereum scaling service platform, AltLayer, has incorporated support for Arbitrum Orbit, enabling users to initiate Arbitrum’s L3 application chains in mere minutes through no-code tools. Furthermore, the Xai network, specifically designed for the gaming industry, announced in June its plans to utilize Arbitrum Orbit technology to launch an L3 blockchain meticulously crafted to cater to the gaming sector.

Together, these networks illustrate Arbitrum’s multifaceted approach to blockchain scalability and functionality, catering to diverse needs and applications within the crypto space.

Optimism

Optimism is a Layer 2 scaling solution built on Optimistic Rollup technology, and it is progressing towards becoming a super chain. Currently, the Optimism network has locked crypto assets valued at 3.04 billion USD, establishing itself as the second-largest Layer 2 network. Its native cryptocurrency, OP, has a market price of $1.61 and a total market capitalization of 1.18 billion USD, ranking 42nd in the crypto asset hierarchy. In comparison to Arbitrum, Optimism’s on-chain ecosystem appears slightly less flourishing. As per DeFiLlama’s statistics, Optimism’s ecosystem encompasses 153 identified applications. Despite this, Optimism has carved a distinct pathway in the Layer landscape by utilizing its OP Stack components, steering towards a realm referred to as the super chain.

OP Stack, developed by Optimism, is a comprehensive open-source toolkit that includes various components such as data availability, execution, settlement, and governance layers. This toolkit enables developers to craft a tailored Layer 2 network that suits their particular requirements.

This innovation led to the introduction of the “super chain” concept within Optimism’s ecosystem. A super chain consists of a collection of standardized Layer 2 blockchains, known as OP chains, constructed on top of OP Stack. Super chains represent a departure from traditional multi-chain architectures, such as those seen in Cosmos. Unlike multi-chain systems, where each chain introduces its own unique consensus algorithm, requiring new validators for each additional chain, super chains maintain standardization across all chains. The consensus algorithms are consistent, and security is upheld by a Layer 1 blockchain (e.g., the Ethereum mainnet). Additionally, this standardization facilitates the sharing of resources and information between chains.

By embracing the super chain structure, Optimism has effectively streamlined the interaction between chains, ensuring uniformity in consensus and security, while allowing for a more seamless integration of information and resources across the network. This creates a more robust and interconnected environment, distinguishing Optimism’s approach from conventional multi-chain solutions.

On June 24th, the Optimism blockchain underwent a rebranding, changing its name to OP Mainnet. This change serves to differentiate OP Mainnet from the multiple Layer 2 networks that form part of the broader Optimism ecosystem and are constructed using the OP Stack toolkit. In essence, OP Mainnet is a foundational chain within the larger structure of the Layer 2 super chain network. The renaming underscores the relationship between OP Mainnet and various other Layer 2 networks, all collaboratively comprising the Optimism super chain ecosystem. It highlights the interconnected nature of these networks and aligns with the strategic emphasis on standardization and integration within the ecosystem.

The OP Stack toolkit by Optimism has fueled various initiatives and collaborations across the blockchain ecosystem. Several projects are leveraging this technology to develop Layer 2 networks, catering to different applications ranging from identity systems to gaming. Here are some notable examples:

  1. Base: Coinbase announced the launch of a Layer 2 network, “Base,” built on OP Stack. The mainnet is currently open to developers for deployment, with public access expected in early August.
  2. opBNB: BNB Chain initiated the Layer 2 testnet “opBNB,” based on OP Stack, with the mainnet anticipated to launch in Q3 2023.
  3. Magi: In April, a16z unveiled a Rollup client solution called “Magi,” created using the OP Stack toolkit.
  4. Worldcoin ID: Worldcoin ID announced plans to build an application chain using OP Stack, focusing on the development of an on-chain identity system ecosystem.
  5. Zora Network: NFT marketplace Zora revealed plans to introduce a Layer 2 network, “Zora Network,” built on OP Stack.
  6. Loot Chain: The Adventure Gold DAO of the Loot ecosystem is employing OP Stack to build a Layer 2 network, “Loot Chain,” utilizing its native token AGLD as a Gas Token.
  7. OPCraft: On-chain game developer Lattice is utilizing OP Stack to create a dedicated blockchain for its virtual world game, “OPCraft.”
  8. Celo: The development organization for Layer 1 public blockchain Celo, known as cLabs, has proposed a transition to convert Celo into a Layer 2 based on the OP Stack framework.

Additionally, several gaming and NFT projects are opting to build their networks using the OP Stack framework, signifying the toolkit’s versatility and appeal to different sectors within the blockchain industry.

In addition to other improvements, Optimism has been diligently focused on enhancing its network’s performance. In June of this year, the company announced the completion of the Bedrock upgrade on its mainnet, leading to significant improvements in various areas. These enhancements included the reduction of transaction fees, decreased deposit confirmation times, and a notable boost in overall performance.

Data from Dune Analytics illustrates the substantial impact of the Bedrock upgrade, with average Gas fees per transaction on the Optimism network falling by roughly 75%. This has positioned the Optimism mainnet as one of the most cost-efficient Ethereum Layer 2 networks for token exchanges, boasting an average transaction Gas fee of just $0.1. The changes underscore Optimism’s unceasing dedication to offering an optimized, user-centric experience.

Metis Network

Metis Network, also known as Metis, originated as a Layer 2 scaling network constructed upon Optimistic Rollup technology. This foundation enabled Metis to significantly diminish the latency in transferring assets from Layer 2 back to Layer 1, reducing withdrawal times to mere hours or even minutes. Given these adjustments, Metis has been recognized as a variant of Optimistic Rollup, with its main network named Andromeda.

On July 13th, the MetisDAO Foundation formally unveiled its newly incubated initiative, ZKM (previously known as Project M), announcing a transition from its existing Optimistic Rollup to a more advanced Hybrid Rollup system. The testnet for ZKM is scheduled for release before the year’s end.

ZKM employs a Hybrid Rollup (Mixed Rollup) mechanism, a novel Layer 2 scaling solution that synergistically combines the distinct features of both Optimistic Rollups and ZK Rollup into a unified Rollup protocol. By integrating the coding simplicity provided by the ORU architecture with the finality, security, and decentralization that ZKRU can offer, this hybrid approach enables prompt withdrawals while safeguarding overall security. This fusion of the best attributes of two existing solutions into a singular Rollup framework highlights Metis’s innovative approach, signaling a promising stride toward more efficient and trustworthy scaling solutions.

The Metis Network, which ranks as the ninth largest among various Layer 2 networks, has a Total Value Locked (TVL) of roughly 82.31 million USD. Andromeda, the network’s main chain, uses the METIS token for on-chain Gas fee payments, with an average cost of 0.0064 USD per transaction. The current market price of the METIS token stands at 15.45 USD, resulting in a market capitalization of 68.8 million USD. According to DeFiLlama data, there are 31 applications on the Metis chain, including mainstream DeFi applications such as Aave, SushiSwap, and Stargate.

Boba Network

Boba Network, founded by Enya, a core contributor to the OMG Foundation, is an Ethereum Layer 2 expansion solution utilizing Optimistic Rollup technology. In April of the previous year, the network successfully raised 45 million USD in a Series A funding round at a valuation of 1.5 billion USD. More than 400 participants contributed to this round, including notable cryptocurrency exchanges like Crypto.com, Huobi, and BitMart.

Distinct from other Layer 2 solutions, Boba Network presents a unique multi-chain Layer 2 extension methodology. It’s designed to enhance not only Ethereum but also any EVM-compatible Layer 1 blockchains, transforming them into Layer 2 networks. Boba L2 has been implemented on various platforms, including Moonbeam, Fantom, Avalanche, and BNBchain.

At present, Boba Network’s on-chain Total Value Locked (TVL) stands at a modest $10.43 million. The network supports 20 applications, featuring well-known platforms like SushiSwap, OolongSwap, and the lending service Bodh Finance.

Mantle network

The Mantle Network, an Optimistic Rollup-based Layer 2 scaling solution, was developed with support from BitDAO and introduced its testnet in January of this year. Being an initiative of the centralized exchange ByBit, Mantle Network is recognized as a Layer 2 network endorsed by ByBit.

Mantle Network unveiled its Alpha version of the mainnet at the EthCC conference in Paris on July 17th. Unlike similar platforms like Arbitrum and Optimism, Mantle Network employs a modular architecture. This unique approach allows the separation of core blockchain functions like execution, consensus, settlement, and data availability onto specialized layers, enhancing network efficiency. By merging Optimistic Rollup with data availability methods, Mantle inherits Ethereum’s robust security while providing more cost-effective and easily accessible data.

In the mainnet configuration of Mantle, the execution layer is managed internally, with consensus and settlement handled by L1 Ethereum. A dedicated service provider called Eigenlayer takes responsibility for data availability, which includes both data storage and release. This setup fosters better on-chain integrity and introduces fresh opportunities for scalability.

In June, BitDAO announced the consolidation of BitDAO, Mantle, and the BIT ecosystem into a single entity known as Mantle. The MNT token was introduced as the unified currency for this ecosystem and will be used for transaction fees. Mantle Network has secured a $200 million investment from BitDAO, and BIT tokens are now interchangeable with MNT at a 1:1 ratio.

Currently, the Mantle Network hosts 89 DApp applications, ranging across areas like DeFi, infrastructure, and gaming.

Currently, zkRollup-based networks are primarily focused on compatibility with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). According to Ethereum’s founder Vitalik Buterin, in his blog post titled “The different types of ZK-EVMs,” this compatibility can be categorized into four types: fully Ethereum-equivalent(Type-1), fully EVM-equivalent(Type-2), almost EVM-equivalent(Type-3), and high-level-language equivalent(Type-4). As shown below.

Polygon and Linea are classified under Type-3, being almost EVM-equivalent. They’ve made certain compromises in equivalence, reducing the time required for proof generation and simplifying EVM development, all with the goal of reaching fully EVM-equivalent, categorized as Type-2. On the other hand, zkSync Era and StarkNet are placed in Type-4, using their unique high-level programming languages. While this approach provides quicker verification times, it comes at the cost of reduced compatibility.

In this context, compatibility pertains to the ability of developers to replicate the experience of working on Ethereum, encompassing factors like the ease or complexity of application deployment. The time taken for proof verification indicates the duration needed for a user’s funds to transfer from L2 to L1. If this process takes several hours, users will be unable to move their funds back to L1 during that time.

ZkSync

ZkSync, developed by the MatterLabs team, is a prominent zkRollup scaling solution employing zkSNARK technology (Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge). In an announcement made in February of the previous year, the network’s versioning was clarified, with zkSync 2.0 renamed as zkSync Era and zkSync 1.0 as zkSync Lite. zkSync Era constitutes a ZK Rollup initiative rooted in zkEVM, ensuring compatibility with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), while zkSync Lite, incompatible with the EVM, primarily targets the payment sector.

As of the current reporting period, the Total Value Locked (TVL) on the zkSync Era chain stands at $436 million. This positions it as the third-ranking entity among an extensive array of Layer2 networks, thereby solidifying its status as a flagship project within the zkRollup landscape.

In an industry development last June, zkSync unveiled ZK Stack, a sophisticated collection of modular open-source components devised for the construction of tailored zkRollup networks. With this toolkit, developers are endowed with the capacity to engineer bespoke zkRollup Layer2 and Layer3 structures, also known as HyperChains.

Additionally, zkSync Era disclosed on July 17 an imminent upgrade to the proof system known as Boojum. This evolution signifies a transition from the existing zkSNARK framework to a zkSTARK-supported proofing mechanism, underscoring the continuous innovation and growth within the zkSync ecosystem.

Starknet

StarkNet, engineered by StarkWare, operates as a zkRollup network extension, employing zkSTARK technology to scale its operations. Within StarkWare’s augmentation strategy, there are two principal components: StarkNet, serving as a Layer2 scaling network with a user-centric approach, and StarkEx, exclusively aimed at providing scalability solutions for existing Ethereum applications, including but not limited to dYdX, DeversiFi, and Immutable X.

As of the present analysis, StarkNet’s prominence is notable, with an on-chain Total Value Locked (TVL) amounting to $108 million, positioning it as the second preeminent zkRollup network. A critical detail, however, is StarkNet’s non-compatibility with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). To surmount this challenge, StarkNet has devised a two-pronged approach: the integration of two projects within its ecosystem, namely kakarot and Warp. The former, kakarot, represents a zkEVM executed on StarkNet using the Cairo programming language and classifies under Type-2.5. Following a successful pre-seed financing round in June of this year, involving stakeholders such as StarkWare and Vitalik Buterin, a testnet launch for kakarot is anticipated imminently. Conversely, Warp functions as a transpiler, translating Solidity code into Cairo, aligning it with Ethereum’s EVM specifications, and is designated as Type-4. This bifurcated approach ensures compatibility across both high-level language constructs (through Warp) and at the EVM stratum (via kakarot).

During the Paris EthCC conference on July 19, StarkWare’s co-founder, Eli Ben-Sasson, unveiled plans for the imminent launch of StarkNet application chains (Appchains), underscoring StarkNet’s capabilities to enable the initiation of bespoke application chains. Further amplifying StarkNet’s innovative trajectory, the crypto liquidity platform Paradigm announced on July 21 the incubation of Paradex, a decentralized perpetual derivatives Layer2 application chain, on StarkNet.

Polygon zkEVM

Polygon zkEVM represents an advanced scaling solution for the Ethereum network, leveraging Layer 2 zkEVM architecture and built upon ZK Rollup technology. The testnet was officially deployed on March 27th.

In June, Polygon disclosed the imminent introduction of the Polygon 2.0 upgrade. This strategic enhancement will see Polygon’s Proof of Stake (PoS) algorithm evolve into zkEVM Validium, aligning it with Zero-Knowledge (ZK) technology protocols. Polygon 2.0, driven by ZK technology, will incorporate a diversified multi-chain Layer 2 network ecosystem, encompassing elements such as zkEVM, PoS, and Supernets subnets. Notably, earlier collaborations with Immutable X and zkMeta underscored Polygon’s commitment to this technological direction, with initiatives targeting specific applications such as gaming.

July marked a significant milestone with the announcement of the conversion of the original MATIC token into POL, accompanied by the publication of a detailed whitepaper for the newly minted POL token. Designed to function across the entire Polygon network, the POL token will have an initial supply of 10 billion and will feature a 2% annual inflation rate. The token is also slated to be adopted as the GAS fee payment instrument within the Polygon PoS chain, providing a versatile asset for ecosystem participants.

Further enhancing its governance framework, the Polygon team revealed plans for Polygon 2.0 on July 13th. This refined model will be underpinned by “three major governance pillars.” Key components include an expansion of the Polygon Improvement Proposal (PIP) framework, the establishment of an ecological committee to oversee system smart contract upgrades and a well-structured community treasury governance system to allocate funding to prospective ecosystem initiatives.

As of the present, Polygon zkEVM’s on-chain Total Value Locked (TVL) amounts to $54.56 million. The network hosts 19 deployed decentralized applications (DApps), including 9 dedicated to data infrastructure and cross-chain bridging. Other notable applications feature financial products such as the stablecoin QiDao, decentralized exchanges Quickswap and Leetswap, lending protocol 0vix, and the Non-Fungible Token (NFT) trading platform Zionic. This rich array of offerings positions Polygon zkEVM as a robust and innovative solution within the blockchain technology landscape.

Linea

Linea, a Zk-rollup-based Layer 2 expansion solution that is compatible with the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), was developed by ConsenSys, the renowned parent company of MetaMask.

During the EthCC conference held on July 18th, ConsenSys made a significant announcement, revealing the official public release of the Linea zkEVM mainnet alpha version. To mark this event, participants involved in the Linea Voyage initiative were awarded specific NFTs as part of an airdrop.

The ecosystem surrounding Linea is robust and diverse, as indicated by Rootdata statistics. The network accommodates 71 projects, featuring deployed solutions such as the LineaBank lending application, the FWDEX decentralized exchange platform, XY Finance (a cross-chain exchange aggregator), Owlto Finance (a cross-Rollup chain), and the Zoni NFT marketplace. Additionally, it hosts mainstream DeFi applications, including but not limited to Aave, Airswap, Sushiswap, and Pancakeswap, some of which are actively being migrated and deployed. The total value locked (TVL) within the Linea chain has reached an impressive $29.05 million.

Addressing inquiries about the possibility of a native token within the Linea network, officials clarified the present strategy. Rather than introducing a separate digital asset, the Linea network leverages Ethereum, bridged directly from the Ethereum mainnet, serving as its ecosystem’s native currency. This approach underlines Linea’s alignment with the broader Ethereum network and its commitment to compatibility.

The end

The ongoing Layer 2 war is a vivid illustration of the relentless innovation and competition in the ever-evolving blockchain landscape. As different Layer 2 solutions vie for supremacy, each boasting unique attributes, compatibility with existing systems, scalability, and various functionalities, the stakes are high. The race to deliver the most efficient, secure, and user-friendly platform is reflective of the broader push to enhance the blockchain’s usability, thereby driving wider adoption.

However, investors must tread cautiously in this rapidly changing environment. The volatility that characterizes the market, particularly within the Layer 2 space, is not to be underestimated. With new technologies being deployed, updates being made, and strategic alignments being formed almost daily, the landscape can shift dramatically in a short period. Investors are urged to diligently research, understand the underlying technologies, evaluate the potential risks, and align their investments with their risk tolerance and long-term goals.

entry.title: How to Analyze DeFi Projects
entry.content:
How to Analyze DeFi Projects

Introduction:

  • This article focuses on explaining the thought process and not on commenting on or analyzing any specific project.
  • Before diving into a deep analysis, understanding the fundamentals of a DeFi project is extremely important.
  • Tracking popular metrics of DeFi protocols can help investors assess the health of the project and evaluate whether it is undervalued or overvalued.
  • By understanding token economics, investors can make wiser decisions about which tokens to buy, sell, and hold.
  • The technology underpinning DeFi projects is a key factor in determining its feasibility and effectiveness.
  • The team’s pursuit of security is of paramount importance.
  • Investors need to be able to identify projects that align with the use cases they believe in and evaluate the team behind them.
  • The strength of a project’s community and the extent to which it is adopted by users are also important indicators of success.

Introduction to DeFi

The explosive growth of Decentralized Finance (DeFi) has fundamentally transformed the financial field, offering a variety of innovative products and services. As a result, individuals can now access unprecedented financial services and products without having to go through intermediaries like banks or traditional financial institutions.

DeFi has made finance more accessible, allowing anyone with an internet connection to participate in activities like lending, trading, and earning interest on their digital assets. However, as more and more projects enter the market, understanding how to effectively analyze DeFi projects has become crucial. This means that investors should conduct thorough due diligence on a project before acquiring its tokens.

Understanding the Basics of DeFi

Before diving into a deep analysis, understanding the fundamentals of a DeFi project is essential. DeFi refers to financial applications built on blockchain networks, aiming to offer open, permissionless, and trustless alternatives to traditional financial services. These projects usually provide services like lending, decentralized exchanges, and liquidity mining.

Considering the open and permissionless nature of this technology, various individuals and teams are building applications that cover many use cases, such as giving users unprecedented control over their personal data and complete ownership of their digital assets. For those new to the DeFi field, they should approach these projects with caution and prudence.

Why is Due Diligence (Risk Management) in DeFi Important?

Due to the unique nature and risks of the rapidly evolving field of DeFi, conducting due diligence before investing or purchasing tokens is extremely important. DeFi investments often come with risks such as potential scams, hacking attacks, and the loss of part or all of the investor’s principal. By thoroughly evaluating a project’s fundamentals, team, technology, and security measures, one can avoid potential scams or bad projects. By conducting due diligence, investors can make decisions, reduce risks, and identify investment opportunities that align with their investment goals and risk tolerance. Moreover, it will help build the necessary knowledge and understanding foundation to invest in the complex and rapidly growing field of DeFi.

This requires individuals involved in the DeFi field to consider the following factors when engaging with new projects.

Fundamentals of the Project

Understanding the core aspects of a project, such as its purpose, utility, value proposition, and roadmap, is key. Assessing the market size and growth potential of the project is also essential. Reading the whitepaper can provide insights into the project’s objectives, use cases, and technology. The track record of team members reveals their ability to build and scale the product. Finally, the roadmap can be used to judge whether the project is proceeding as planned. It can serve as a supplement to other research, determining the likelihood of the project reaching its milestone goals.

Popular metrics of DeFi Protocols

There are several popular indicators that can provide valuable references to understand the performance and potential of a DeFi project. These include the token’s Total Value Locked (TVL), 24-hour trading volume, inflation rate, price, and market cap.

Total Value Locked (TVL)

Total Value Locked (TVL) is the total amount of funds locked in a DeFi protocol. You can view TVL as the total amount deposited by liquidity providers into a protocol. For example, as of July 2023, Uniswap’s TVL exceeds 3.8 billion USD, meaning users have deposited more than $3.8 billion into Uniswap. You can review TVL to assess the overall interest in a specific DeFi protocol or use it to compare which DeFi protocols have “locked” more value. Attracting substantial TVL is often a sign of a strong project.

Market Cap

The market cap reflects the total value of circulating tokens in a DeFi protocol. It is calculated by multiplying the current price of the token by the number of tokens in circulation. The market cap provides an overall assessment of the protocol’s size and prominence. However, it must be considered in conjunction with other factors such as the utility of the protocol and competition.

24-hour Trading Volume

The 24-hour trading volume measures the total value of transactions executed in a specific DeFi protocol over a 24-hour span. A high 24-hour trading volume indicates that the project is more active and has better liquidity, reflecting an active ecosystem and increased market interest. Conversely, a low 24-hour trading volume shows less buying and selling of the protocol’s tokens, and lower liquidity. Low 24-hour trading volume may signify a lack of interest or participation from traders and investors.

Inflation Rate

Another important indicator is the inflation rate, referring to the rate at which new tokens are generated within the DeFi protocol. A lower inflation rate might be favorable, as it indicates a more controllable token supply, possibly increasing in value over time, such as ETH transitioning to a deflationary state after moving to POS, and BTC halving, where the new BTC output will be halved. However, assessing the overall token economy and allocation model to ensure a balance between incentivizing participants and maintaining token scarcity is crucial. This topic will be further explored in this article.

Market Cap to Total Value Locked Ratio (TVL Ratio)

The Market Cap to TVL ratio provides investors with information about the relationship between a DeFi project’s valuation and demand. For example, if a protocol’s token market cap is low but its TVL is high, it may mean that the token is undervalued. If a token’s TVL ratio is below 1, it may be more attractive, suitable for potential investors.

Number of Addresses

The number of wallet addresses is an indicator that measures the number of DeFi protocol participants. Similar to the user numbers of traditional Web2 applications, it is used to gauge user engagement. An increase in address numbers may be a good sign of growing popularity and adoption. It should be noted that this metric might be manipulated, as in the case of airdrops where an investor might have multiple addresses. Investors should use this metric in conjunction with other indicators.

Tokenomics

Tokenomics is a term that originates from the fusion of “token” and “economics.” It is a key concept in the cryptocurrency domain, referring to the economic principles and incentive systems for managing the creation, distribution, and value of tokens within a specific blockchain system.

Here are some aspects that tokenomics considers:

  • Token Supply and Issuance: This involves the total number of existing or to-be-issued tokens. Some tokens have a fixed supply, while others may have a mechanism to mint new tokens. Issuance mechanisms can significantly influence the price and overall economy of the tokens. Fixed supply may lead to scarcity and possibly increase the price but might limit the system’s flexibility. Mintable tokens offer greater flexibility but could lead to inflation if mismanaged. For example, MATIC originally had a fixed supply cap of 10 billion, while the POL white paper allows for a specific rate of annual increase beyond the initial supply of 10 billion (all converted from MATIC).

  • Token Distribution: How tokens are distributed among users can greatly impact the health and sustainability of the token economy. Fair and reasonable distribution helps maintain a healthy and active user base. Additionally, tokens may be distributed according to a vesting schedule, meaning they can be used within specific periods. This can encourage long-term holding and contribute to the token’s stability.

  • Token Utility: Tokens usually serve specific functions within their ecosystem. They can provide services, voting rights, or other benefits to users. The utility of a token is a key factor in determining its value. Tokens that provide services, voting rights, or other benefits are more likely to retain value than those without clear use cases.

  • Mining and Staking Incentives: Many blockchain projects reward users for contributing to network security and stability with newly minted tokens, a practice known as mining or staking. Participation in incentive measures like staking rewards can encourage user engagement. However, this must be balanced to avoid vicious inflation or other unintended consequences.

  • Token Burning: Some projects may choose to periodically “burn” tokens, permanently removing them from circulation to reduce supply and potentially increase the value of the remaining tokens.

  • Governance: Many tokens also serve as governance tokens, granting holders voting rights over the project’s future decisions.

  • Economic Policies: Tokenomics involves implementing economic policies at the protocol level, influencing how tokens are issued, distributed, and managed.

  • Security: The security of tokens and their underlying blockchain technology is crucial. This includes the security of smart contracts managing the tokens and the overall security of the blockchain.

Tokenomics is vital as it shapes the dynamics of digital assets and projects. By understanding tokenomics, investors can make more informed decisions about buying and holding particular tokens. It can also help project developers design more sustainable and successful token economies. Equally important, remember that the above-mentioned aspects are just things to consider; the “best” token economy may vary depending on the specific goals of the project. For instance, tokens aimed at incentivizing participation in decentralized applications may have different requirements compared to tokens intended to act as stablecoins.

Assessing DeFi Technology

The technology that underpins DeFi (Decentralized Finance) projects is a critical factor in determining their feasibility and effectiveness. One of the key aspects to consider is the blockchain platform on which the project is built. For example, Ethereum is a popular choice, providing a robust and mature infrastructure for DeFi applications. Meanwhile, with the development of Layer 2 solutions, more and more projects are seeking collaboration with OP and ARB. Other Layer 1 blockchain have also emerged, offering promising options for scalable DeFi applications. Investors seeking to acquire DeFi tokens should weigh the pros and cons of the underlying blockchain to make an informed decision.

Another crucial aspect is the assessment of the smart contracts that drive the DeFi projects. Smart contracts are self-executing contracts on the blockchain, with the terms of the agreement directly written into code. Although audits may not necessarily guarantee security, it is vital for DeFi projects to regularly audit their smart contracts to reduce potential vulnerabilities and protect user funds. Reviewing the smart contract audit history of a project can give insights into the team’s efforts to protect users.

Interoperability is another key aspect of DeFi tokens, ensuring seamless communication and interaction between different platforms and protocols. It allows tokens to be easily transferred, traded, and used across multiple decentralized applications (DApps) and blockchain networks. Investors should check the interoperability of DeFi tokens before deciding to invest.

Security

Given the frequent occurrence of security vulnerabilities in the DeFi (Decentralized Finance) sector, assessing a project’s security measures is crucial. Regular audits by reputable third-party companies, which indicate that the project is actively identifying potential vulnerabilities to ensure the security of smart contracts, are a positive sign. Considering the history of DeFi projects being targeted by hackers and the subsequent panic that ensues, robust security measures are a necessity.

In addition to audits, incentives similar to bounty hunters exist, such as bug bounty programs, which serve as another indicator of the project’s serious commitment to security. In a bug bounty program, the organization sets specific standards, guidelines, and rewards for individuals who discover and responsibly disclose valid security vulnerabilities. When bug finders identify vulnerabilities, they can submit a detailed report to the organization, outlining the issue, its impact, and the steps to reproduce the flaw. The organization then verifies the reported vulnerability, and if valid, offers a bounty or predetermined monetary reward to the bug-finder. This proactive approach to security encourages a community of security researchers to help improve the overall safety and resilience of the DeFi project.

Team

The following are common points to consider in team assessment for stock investments, which may be enlightening for evaluating teams within DeFi (Decentralized Finance) projects:

  • Assessing the Skills, Experience, and Qualifications of Team Members: Look for signs of success in similar enterprises or industries. The collective ability of the team should align with the company’s mission and goals.
  • Researching the Team’s Compensation Structure: This includes salary, bonuses, and stock options (or token allocation in the context of DeFi). Stock options can inflate compensation figures and affect shareholder value. High compensation that doesn’t align with the company’s performance might be a warning signal.
  • Observing Insider Buying and Stock (or Token) Repurchases: If management is purchasing company stock (or tokens), it might indicate their confidence in the company’s future. Conversely, if management is selling stock (or tokens), it may signal potential problems.
  • Paying Attention to How Management Communicates with Shareholders and the Public: Transparency, regular updates, and a clear vision for the company’s future are all signs of strong leadership. Questions can be asked through social media, community channels, and AMAs (Ask Me Anything sessions).
  • Company Policies and Mission Statements: These can provide deep insights into management’s values and strategic direction. Look for evidence of ethical practices and a focus on long-term profitability.
  • Being Alert to Potential Red Flags: Such as past fraudulent activities or ongoing legal issues.

In the context of DeFi projects, these traditional considerations take on new dimensions, given the decentralized and often pseudonymous nature of blockchain projects. Still, careful analysis of the team’s background, alignment with project goals, compensation structure, and communication strategy can provide valuable insights into the project’s credibility, alignment with stakeholders’ interests, and long-term viability.

Community and Social Media

The strength of a project’s community and user adoption is a key indicator of its potential success. These metrics provide valuable insights into the project’s viability, future growth prospects, and overall market acceptance.

  • **Emotions and Engagement: **Emotion is an essential factor in trading and also a reflection of the strength of a project’s community. Engaging with the project’s community is vital to deeply understanding their sentiment, active participation, and overall enthusiasm. This interaction allows you to assess the levels of support, engagement, and trust within the community.
  • **Social Media Platforms: **Platforms like Twitter, Telegram, Discord, and even WeChat provide abundant information about the project community. Investors should monitor discussions, comments, and activity levels on these platforms, looking for signs of positive sentiment, active discussions, and growing follower numbers.
  • Positive Sentiment: Positive sentiment indicates community trust and enthusiasm for the project. It’s often reflected in the tone and content of discussions within social media channels.
  • Community Activities: Participation in community forums, AMAs (Ask Me Anything sessions), and active community channels often indicates a thriving community that is engaged and supportive of the project.
  • Warning Signs: On the flip side, investors should be cautious about manipulated sentiment, paid influencers, or unnatural spikes in activity that could be signs of artificial hype or misleading marketing strategies.
  • Importance of Community in DeFi: In the world of decentralized finance (DeFi), community plays an even more significant role. Decisions related to the development and direction of a project often involve community voting and active participation from the stakeholders. A strong community can foster innovation, support the project through challenges, and contribute to the decentralized ethos that underpins these projects.

Evaluating the community and social media presence of a DeFi project is a multifaceted task. It requires a nuanced understanding of various platforms, the ability to discern genuine sentiment from manipulation, and an appreciation for the role of the community in driving project success. Combined with other assessment factors like technology, security, and team evaluation, community analysis offers a holistic view of a project’s potential and can guide wise investment decisions.

VC investment

Venture Capital (VC) investment in a crypto project can have substantial impacts, both positive and negative. Here’s an analysis of how VC investment may affect a crypto or decentralized finance (DeFi) project:

Positive Impacts

  • Increased Capital: VC funding provides the necessary capital to scale the project, develop technology, hire talent, and execute the roadmap. It can accelerate growth and enable the project to reach milestones more quickly.

  • Network and Expertise: VCs often come with vast industry networks and strategic insights. These connections can help in forming partnerships, gaining market insights, and providing mentorship to the team.

  • Trust: Backing from renowned VCs can bring trust to the project. It signals trust and often attracts further institutional and retail interest.

  • Marketing and Community Building: VC investment can facilitate more substantial marketing efforts and community engagement, which can result in better visibility and adoption.

Negative Impacts

  • Control and Decision-making: Depending on the terms, VC investment may come with conditions that affect control and decision-making within the project. VCs might seek seats on the board or have a say in major decisions, potentially leading to conflicts with the original vision of the founders.

  • Token Distribution and Economics: If not managed carefully, the token distribution to VCs might affect the token economics, potentially leading to an oversupply or concentration of tokens with a few entities. This can impact price stability and community dynamics.

  • Exit Pressure: VC funds usually seek returns on their investment within a defined period. This can lead to pressures on the project to deliver financial results, sometimes at the expense of long-term innovation or community interests.

  • Potential Misalignment with Decentralization Ethos: In some cases, VC involvement might be seen as contrary to the decentralized ethos of crypto projects, especially if there’s significant control exerted by the VCs. This could lead to community backlash or a shift away from the project’s original decentralized mission.

VC investment in a crypto project is a multifaceted aspect that carries both opportunities and challenges. While it provides much-needed capital and potential strategic advantages, it also introduces complexities related to control, token economics, and alignment with the project’s vision and values.

Projects considering VC investment must carefully assess and negotiate the terms to ensure alignment with their long-term goals, community interests, and decentralized principles if they pertain to the specific project. Transparency with the community and stakeholders about the nature and terms of the investment can also be vital in maintaining trust and alignment.

Conclusion

Analyzing DeFi projects is a critical process in making informed investment decisions in the rapidly expanding field of decentralized finance. While the factors outlined above are essential for making wise choices, what’s even more vital is that investments should never exceed what one can afford to lose. Investors should proceed with caution, not only fully understanding the technical foundation, security measures, team competence, community engagement, and social media impact of the project but also scrutinizing potential risks and market volatility. VC investment may bring new opportunities and challenges, and this too requires careful assessment. Ultimately, investing in DeFi or any crypto projects should be based on comprehensive research and understanding, coupled with clear investment strategies and risk management plans. While pursuing returns, maintaining caution and responsibility is of paramount importance.

entry.content:
从ETHGlobal Waterloo 2023 Hackathon决赛入围项目了解 ERC-6551

在入围ETHGlobal Waterloo 2023黑客松决赛的11个项目中有4个和ERC-6551相关，提供了多功能性和实用性，使它们成为更强大的数字资产，为NFT市场带来了新的活力。以下是4个项目的简介。

  1. AquaNet: https://ethglobal.com/showcase/aquanet-dzz2c

    AquaNet是一个应用程序，它利用非同质化代币绑定账户（ERC-6551）使NFT能够在一个基于NFT的、由AI驱动的社交媒体网络中创建并记录其活动。每个符合条件的NFT都可以在’myPuddle’网络上创建自己的账户，使NFT能够建立并发展出一个独特的AI身份，这主要是由其现有特性生成的。它们将自动向其账户发布消息，列出其兴趣，并分享关于自己的信息。

    AquaNet的个人资料只能铸造到Tokenbound账户。一旦铸造了AquaNet的个人资料，后端会自动索引该事件并开始创建个人资料。OpenAI的GPT-3.5用于根据NFT的元数据生成用户名、简介和语气。基于个人资料的发布频率，会定期自动生成帖子，并使用个人资料的语气生成。

  2. Fukuro: https://ethglobal.com/showcase/fukuro-3cdwv

    Fukuro是一个利用EIP-6551创建拍卖市场的项目。用户可以在Fukuro上列出和出价购买捆绑包。Fukuro这个名字的灵感来自于日本的福袋（Fukubukuro），也被称为“幸运袋”。它们是神秘的密封袋，以固定价格出售。EIP 6551使得ERC721能够控制自己的“钱包地址”并持有资产。每个Fukuro可以包含任何以太坊地址可以包含的东西，包括其他NFT、ERC20代币等等。这使得可以交易各种各样的资产，从艺术收藏、交易卡片套装，甚至是精选的投资组合。

  3. Piggybank 6551 NFT: https://ethglobal.com/showcase/piggybank-6551-nft-e2ai5

    Piggybank 6551是一个有趣的NFT储蓄账户。用户可以铸造Piggybank NFT，然后通过一个可支付的函数或者直接向NFT的6551账户地址发送ETH来给它们充值。随着每个Piggybank中ETH的积累，NFT元数据的颜色、文本标签和属性会立即更新。一旦ETH被锁定在NFT中，提取它的唯一方式就是销毁NFT。

  4. Tokenbound Titans: https://ethglobal.com/showcase/tokenbound-titans-5w6oq

    Tokenbound Titans是一个基于ERC-6551，结合了动态生成NFT的NPC游戏。玩家是以NFT形式存在的NPC的拥有者，每个NFT对应的NPC都拥有不同的能力和特性。游戏的玩法围绕这些NPC之间的战斗展开，玩家可以在数字竞技场中策略性地对彼此下注。计算战斗结果的算法是链下的，并可以使用ZK-proof进行验证。

    在战斗中获胜会奖励玩家让他们的NPC升级，这会增强健康、攻击、速度和装甲等属性，也能够为他们的NFT解锁新的能力和组合。随着NFT的升级，它们变得更强大、更多样化。这种进步系统为游戏增加了深度和持久性，激励玩家制定策略、适应并不断提高他们的NFT以主导游戏景观。

Blur的出现给NFT市场带来了短暂的欢愉，同时伴随着NFT早期玩家出货，蓝筹NFT的价格下跌和市场对Azuki Elements的不满，都在诉说NFT市场惨淡。此前，NFT的作用大致可分为：艺术品，PFP，Pass Card，抵押品等。此时，对于视NFT为艺术品的藏家来说，可能是个好时机，只是此类玩家占比依旧是极少数（本人是不相信绝大多数币，图是具有实际价值的），另一个可能是市场在探索NFT可能带来的新的故事。

ERC-6551是什么？

ERC-6551是一项以太坊改进提案，该提案定义了一个系统，该系统为每个ERC-721代币提供一个智能合约账户。这些被称为”代币绑定账户”的账户允许ERC-721代币拥有资产并与应用程序交互，而无需更改现有的ERC-721智能合约或基础设施。简而言之，就是将过去的NFT变成一个个钱包，钱包里可以存在NFT，以及其他代币（参考Fukuro项目）。这不仅仅是实现了增量，同时也给过去的NFT（存量）带来了新可能。

ERC-721代币正在越来越多地成为链上身份的一种形式（PFP）。然而，与其他形式的链上身份不同，ERC-721代币不能作为代理或与其他链上资产关联（DID项目比如.eth和.bnb）。这个限制与许多现实世界中的非同质资产实例形成了对比。例如，角色扮演游戏中的角色随着他们所采取的行动积累资产和能力（参考Tokenbound Titans项目的愿景；可以通过钱包买卖多种代币），自动化投资组合由多种同质资产组成（比如一个银行账号中有多种理财，定存等；钱包中也有代币和NFT等），一张可以进入某个场所并记录过去互动历史的打孔通行证（现实生活中的行程码；钱包中多个币的交易记录）。

这个提案通过一个无需许可的注册表为每个ERC-721代币部署唯一的、确定性地址的智能合约账户，从而赋予每个ERC-721代币以太坊账户的全部功能，同时保持与之前部署的ERC-721代币合约的向后兼容性。每个代币绑定账户都由一个ERC-721代币拥有，允许代币与区块链交互，记录交易历史，并拥有链上资产。每个代币绑定账户的控制权被委托给ERC-721代币的所有者，允许所有者代表他们的代币发起链上行动。

代币绑定账户与几乎所有支持以太坊账户的现有基础设施都兼容，从链上协议到链下索引器。代币绑定账户可以拥有任何类型的链上资产，并可以扩展以支持未来创建的新资产类型。

ERC-6551 是如何实现的？

ERC-6551的实现主要依赖于两个主要组件：

  1. 无需许可的注册表：用于部署代币绑定账户。
  2. 代币绑定账户实现的标准接口。

注册表是项目希望使用代币绑定账户的单一入口点。它有两个功能：

  • createAccount：给定实现地址为ERC-721代币部署一个代币绑定账户。
  • account：一个只读函数，给定实现地址计算ERC-721代币的代币绑定账户地址。

注册表将每个代币绑定账户部署为具有附加的不可变常量数据的ERC-1167最小代理。每个代币绑定账户的部署字节码都有特定的结构。每个代币绑定账户代理将执行委托给实现IERC6551Account接口的合约。注册表合约是无需许可的，不可变的，并且没有所有者。所有的代币绑定账户都应通过注册表创建。所有代币绑定账户实现都必须实现ERC-165接口检测。所有代币绑定账户实现都必须实现ERC-1271签名验证。所有代币绑定账户实现都必须实现特定的接口。

ERC-6551有哪些特性以及可能性

  • NFT资产所有权：ERC-6551 使 NFT 能够直接拥有自己的钱包和托管资产。 这意味着 NFT 可以在其内部存储各种代币，包括 ETH，甚至可以持有其他 NFT。 这与当前 NFT 无法拥有或与其他链上资产关联的限制相比是一个重大飞跃。
  • 简化交易交易：该标准带来了许多优势，例如简化交易角色和 NFT 集的交易、提高市场效率。 这可以使 NFT 交易过程更加高效且用户友好。还可以为 NFT 市场的潜在买家和卖家提供更多透明度和信息。（参考Fukuro交易整个集合）目前的 NFT，并不具备 “自主存储历史记录” 的能力，如果想要查看一张 NFT 的交易记录，只能前往第三方的交易所查看相关记录。 同样的，“签名的控制权、链接的所有权”等一些至关重要的功能也是 NFT 无法自主实现的，只能依赖去中心化钱包。在此附上第一个ERC-6551NFT项目。Sapienz：https://opensea.io/collection/sapienz。
  • 与AI交互：ERC-6551也开启了NFT与AI交互的可能性。 这可以带来创新的应用程序和用例，例如带有自己钱包的人工智能化身。在AI中一直有一个方向即开发AI Agent（代理人），比如AI管家帮助梳理日程，让ChatGPT扮演顾问的角色也是一种AI Agent。 如果将来你的AI管家的外表是一只猴子NFT，它还拥有ETH，OP等代币，可以为你的晚餐点披萨呢？又或者帮你进行投资呢？
  • 在游戏、元宇宙中的潜力：假设在Pokemon go（宝可梦GO！）游戏中，玩家扮演角色，角色拥有不同的宝可梦（NFT），宝可梦可以通过打怪升级增加技能点数，培养性格等等。在Tokenbound Titans游戏中，不同的NPC都拥有不同的能力和特性，升级后也可以有不同的组合。目前在养成类游戏，卡牌类游戏中有可预见的契合度。在元宇宙中，可以设想装备数字服装和物品，或许有一天会出现像普拉达的古驰。
  • DID: 可以应用于目前依靠NFT进行空投代币的场景；又或者将NFT 作为链上身份（参考AquaNet项目），具有在社交属性，下次见面：你好，这是我的Doodles。
  • 向后兼容性：最值得注意的是，ERC-6551 可以兼容现有的 NFT，无需包装或合约升级。 这意味着它可以在不破坏现有 NFT 生态系统的情况下被采用。

ERC-6551目前的风险

  • 价值赋能：一项新的协议可能是一个进步，但市场需要的不是新的技术或协议，而是这个技术和协议所能解决什么样的问题，多大程度地解决什么样用户的什么问题。目前市场上大多数币和图都是不具备实际价值的，投机，交易需谨慎。
  • 用户体验和理解：用户友好的体验和理解对于采用是必要的。 ERC-6551 带来的复杂性可能会让用户更难理解这些 NFT 并与之交互。 这可能对其广泛采用构成障碍。目前Crypto中的很多应用都需要考虑用户体验的问题，这也是所有产品服务发展中不可避免的问题。
  • 平台兼容问题：一些 NFT 平台可能不兼容或缺乏与 ERC-6551 集成所需的技术，获得现有 NFT 项目和平台的支持可能是一个挑战 。 由于ERC-6551是一个新标准，它在NFT社区得到广泛采用可能还需要时间。 这可能会减缓其潜在的影响和效益。
  • 安全问题：由于NFT可以与其他DApp进行交互以及因其增强的功能而变得更具吸引力，它们也可能对黑客变得更有吸引力。
  • Gas Fee: ERC-6551 代币在以太坊网络拥堵期间可能会变得昂贵。

总而言之，ERC-6551 有潜力通过解决 NFT 当前的局限性并为未来开辟新的可能性来彻底改变 NFT 生态系统，但它也有其自身的一系列潜在风险和挑战，需要仔细考虑和解决。
